Expectation1: Assist patients with daily living activities such as bathing, dressing, and eating
Situation1: A patient is recovering from a recent surgery and requires more careful assistance to move and get dressed.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: An urgent directive from the coordinator outlines mandatory procedures that must be followed to avoid shutting down the service.
Story: I was helping Mr. Lee, who had just come out of surgery, gently sit up in bed. He winced with every movement, and I knew he needed extra care to avoid reopening his stitches. As a nursing assistant, my priority was to make sure he was safe and comfortable, so I moved slowly, supporting his back and legs. Just then, my phone buzzed with a message from the volunteer coordinator: an urgent directive had come through. All volunteers were to immediately implement new safety procedures, or the service would be suspended. The message was clear—no exceptions, no delays. My mind raced. If I left Mr. Lee now to follow the coordinator’s instructions, he could be at risk. But if I ignored the directive, I’d be going against the volunteer guidelines and possibly jeopardizing the entire program. My hands trembled as I tried to focus on Mr. Lee’s needs, but the weight of the coordinator’s expectations pressed down on me. I stood there, torn between my duty to my patient and my responsibility as a volunteer, unsure which role to answer first.
